Specific Details: Meeting request with Minister to discuss current tourism performance, lack of ambition in national tourism targets, adequate tourism investment, retaining competitiveness, Dublin capacity issues, adequate supply of skilled staff, Tourism Agencies, reactivating the Tourism Leadership Group, restoring destination marketing budgets
DPOs Lobbied: Shane Ross|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Patrick O'Donovan|Minister of State|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport
Subject Matter: Meeting request with Minister to discuss current tourism performance, lack of ambition in national tourism targets, adequate tourism investment, retaining competitiveness, Dublin capacity issues, adequate supply of skilled staff, Tourism Agencies, reactivating the Tourism Leadership Group, restoring destination marketing budgets
Intended Results: That the correct policies and investment strategies are put in place to allow the tourism industry realise its full potential.::A review of the national tourism target with a revision upwards to 4% annual growth.::That multi-annual capital funding of €300 million over 5 years (2016-21) is secured.::Retention of the tourism Vat rate of 9%, rising minimum wages and utility costs mean that Ireland risk becoming out of line with our competitors. Retaining competitiveness is key to continued growth.::Adequate capacity is a major challenge in Dublin and a critical issue for Irish tourism, and is set to continue to 2020. Ensure that the correct policy recommendations and analysis be strong and proactive in the review of Dublin's hotel capacity.::Ensure there is an adequate supply of skilled staff in the tourism sector, and the recommendations made by the Export Group on Future Skills Needs are implemented.::An independent evaluation of Ireland's overseas tourism marketing expenditure with the inclusion of the tourism industry, and a review of product development to ensure Ireland is providing appropriate things to see and do for visitors.::Re-establishment of the Tourism Leadership Group.::Restoration of Tourism Ireland's marketing funds by 40%.

Specific Details: Presentation of ITIC's report on public transport and its potential for tourism in Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Shane Ross|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Patrick O'Donovan|Minister of State|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Graham Doyle|Secretary General|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Ken Spratt|Assistant Secretary|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Ray O'Leary|Assistant Secretary|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport

Specific Details: Government plans to regulate the short-term letting sector - The ISCF members are experiencing an increasing number of operators being served with enforcement notices to cease trading in their short-term rental properties. There is an alarming trend that has the potential to negatively impact the livelihoods of many of our members in Dublin as well as the wider tourism economy of the country.
DPOs Lobbied: Brendan Griffin|Minister of State|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Shane Ross|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Maria Bailey|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Patrick O'Donovan|Minister of State|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Eoghan Murphy|Minister|Department of Housing, Planning, Community and Local Government
Subject Matter: Government plans to regulate the short-term letting sector - The ISCF members are experiencing an increasing number of operators being served with enforcement notices to cease trading in their short-term rental properties. There is an alarming trend that has the potential to negatively impact the livelihoods of many of our members in Dublin as well as the wider tourism economy of the country.
Intended Results: To highlight the contribution of self catering rental accommodation::To challenge the government view, that short term letting is responsible for the high number of properties not being available for long term rental or causing the homeless crisis
Lobbying Activities: The Minister for Housing set up a committee to investigate this issue. We have attended many meetings with all sections of this committee, Fáilte Ireland, Dublin City Council, Minister of Tourism Brendan Griffin, Maria Bailey Chairperson of the Oireachtas committee and Paul Dunne, Chairman of the investigating committee in the Department of Housing. The ISCF lodged a submission to the investigation committee Chairperson, the Department of Tourism and the Maria Bailey chairperson of the Oireachtas committee.|Submission|1::|Meeting|2-5

Specific Details: Flooding Issues on the River Shannon
DPOs Lobbied: Patrick O'Donovan|Minister of State|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Michael O'Connor|Special Adviser|The Office of Public Works
Subject Matter: Flooding Issues on the River Shannon
Intended Results: To highlight the rise of the Water levels on the River Shannon and to request better management on the river to stop flooding on the Callows.::To request that the Office of Public Works (OPW) manage the water levels on the River Shannon by dropping the water levels while ensuring that it doesn't cause problems further downstream.::To highlight that, in order to to avoid substantial crop losses and livestock being left without winter housing, farmers need the Minister to take immediate control of the situation and ensure that the water levels are managed appropriately to reduce the risk of flooding. This will enable farmers to save valuable crops.::To request that, in the longer term, an agency must be established which would include local farmers to manage the overall Shannon project to rectify the problems and maintain the river thereafter.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Pat Murphy IFA Connaught Regional Chair,  Rachel Moloney IFA Policy Executive

Specific Details: Inclusion of the private and independent higher education sector in the development of the national disability supports policy development.
DPOs Lobbied: Patrick O'Donovan |Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science::Keith Moynes|Assistant Secretary|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: Inclusion of the private and independent higher education sector in the development of the national disability supports policy development.
Intended Results: The inclusion of the private & independent higher education sector in ongoing and future discussions on enhancing disability supports within tertiary education. The objective aligns with Minister O’Donovan’s vision of an inclusive education system, aiming to ensure equitable support frameworks for all students with disabilities. By HECA participating, we seek to provide sector-specific insights, fostering uniform accessibility and improving outcomes across all higher education institutions.
